topics.definition: A contract between an insurance company (insurer) and a policyholder (insured) where the insurer promises to pay a specified amount in case of a specific event in exchange for a premium.
key_points: Provides financial protection against risks and uncertainties.
Policyholder pays premium; insurer pays claim on occurrence of insured event.
Helps in risk pooling – losses of a few are shared by many.
Cannot prevent events but compensates financial loss.
processes: Identify risk to be insured (life, health, vehicle, home, etc.).
Choose insurance type and policy term.
Pay regular premiums.
In case of event, file claim with insurer.
Insurer verifies and pays sum assured to insured/nominee.
examples: Life insurance pays nominee on death of insured.
Motor insurance covers repair costs after accident.
Health insurance pays for hospitalization expenses.
facts: First life insurance company in India: Oriental Life Insurance Co. (1818).
General insurance nationalized in 1973; life insurance in 1956.
IRDAI regulates insurance industry in India.
Insurance sector reopened to private players in late 1990s.

topics.definition: Different categories of insurance designed to cover specific risks related to life, health, property, travel, and vehicles.
key_points: Life Insurance: Covers human life risks – death, disability, retirement.
Health Insurance: Covers medical and surgical expenses.
Motor Insurance: Covers vehicle against accident, theft, third-party liability.
Home Insurance: Covers house and contents against fire, theft, natural disasters.
Travel Insurance: Covers losses during travel – medical, baggage loss, trip cancellation.
processes: Assess personal/family risks and needs.
Compare policies from different insurers.
Select appropriate type and sum assured.
Fill proposal form, undergo medical tests if required.
Pay premium and receive policy document.
examples: Term life insurance for income replacement.
Cashless health insurance at network hospitals.
Comprehensive motor insurance for own damage + third party.
Group insurance for villages/communities.
facts: Motor third-party insurance is compulsory by law.
Group insurance is cheaper than individual policies.
Insurance helps in economic stability by accumulating and investing funds.

topics.definition: Financial institutions that accept deposits from the public and provide loans; classified by function, ownership, and area of operation.
key_points: Commercial Banks: Serve general public and businesses.
Cooperative Banks: Serve members, often in rural/urban cooperative societies.
Regional Rural Banks (RRBs): Focus on rural credit and agriculture.
Public Sector Banks: Government-owned (e.g., SBI, nationalized banks).
Private Sector Banks: Privately owned (e.g., HDFC, ICICI).
Foreign Banks: Headquartered outside India (e.g., Citibank, HSBC).
processes: Bank accepts deposits (savings, current, fixed).
Uses deposits to give loans to borrowers.
Earns from interest difference (lending rate – deposit rate).
Provides payment services (cheques, drafts, electronic transfers).
examples: Savings account in a public sector bank.
Agricultural loan from a Regional Rural Bank.
Business account in a private sector bank.
facts: Scheduled banks are listed in RBI’s Second Schedule.
RBI is the central bank and regulator of banking system.
Cooperative banks play key role in agricultural and rural finance.

topics.definition: A cheque is a written order to a bank to pay a specific amount from the drawer’s account to the payee. MICR is a technology used for secure cheque processing.
key_points: Cheque contains drawer’s name, bank details, amount, date, signature.
Types: bearer, order, crossed, uncrossed, ante-dated, post-dated, stale.
MICR (Magnetic Ink Character Recognition) code is printed at bottom.
MICR ensures fast, error-free cheque clearing.
processes: Drawer writes cheque in favor of payee.
Payee deposits cheque in their bank.
Bank sends cheque for clearing via MICR system.
Funds are transferred from drawer’s to payee’s account.
examples: Crossed cheque with “A/c Payee” for safety.
Bearer cheque encashable by anyone holding it.
MICR code 110002033 – first 3 digits: city, next 3: bank, last 3: branch.
facts: Cheque is valid for 3 months from date of issue.
Stale cheque is older than 3 months and not honoured.
MICR uses special ink containing iron oxide.

topics.definition: A compulsory financial charge imposed by government on individuals and businesses to fund public services and infrastructure.
key_points: Income Tax: Levied on personal or business income.
Property Tax: Levied on buildings and land by local government.
GST (Goods and Services Tax): Indirect tax on supply of goods and services.
Taxes fund roads, schools, hospitals, defense, etc.
processes: Taxpayer earns income or makes purchase.
Tax is deducted or collected at source.
Taxpayer files return annually (for direct taxes).
Government uses revenue for public welfare.
examples: Income tax paid by salaried employee.
GST included in bill when buying clothes.
Property tax paid annually to municipal corporation.
facts: GST replaced multiple indirect taxes (VAT, excise, service tax).
GST is multi-stage, destination-based tax.
Alcohol, petroleum products, electricity are outside GST currently.

topics.definition: A comprehensive, multi-stage, destination-based indirect tax levied on every value addition in the supply chain of goods and services.
key_points: Multi-stage: Tax levied at each stage of production and distribution.
Value addition: Tax on increase in value at each stage.
Destination-based: Tax revenue goes to state where goods/services are consumed.
Components: CGST (Central), SGST/UTGST (State/UT), IGST (Inter-state).
processes: Manufacturer pays GST on raw materials.
Adds value, sells to wholesaler – charges GST.
Wholesaler sells to retailer – charges GST.
Retailer sells to consumer – final GST paid by consumer.
examples: Goods made in Rajasthan sold in Karnataka – IGST goes to Karnataka.
GST on restaurant meal includes CGST + SGST.
facts: Implemented on 1 July 2017.
Aims to create unified national market.
Reduces cascading effect of tax-on-tax.

topics.definition: Procedure to open and operate a bank account for depositing, withdrawing, and managing money.
key_points: Types: Savings, Current, Recurring Deposit, Fixed Deposit.
Required documents: Proof of identity, address, photographs.
KYC norms: Know Your Customer – mandatory verification.
Children’s accounts can be opened by parent/guardian.
processes: Fill account opening form.
Submit documents and photographs.
Provide specimen signature.
Deposit minimum balance.
Receive passbook, cheque book, debit card.
examples: Minor above 10 years can operate savings account independently.
Joint account in two names.
Zero-balance account under financial inclusion.
facts: Passbook records all transactions.
Withdrawal slip used to withdraw cash from own account.
Deposit slip used to deposit money into any account.

topics.definition: A secure payment instrument issued by a bank, directing another branch/bank to pay a specified amount to a named beneficiary.
key_points: Safer than cheque because drawer is bank, not individual.
Valid for 6 months.
Requires payment of amount + commission + tax.
Used for secure remittance, especially outstation payments.
processes: Applicant fills DD request form.
Pays amount + charges in cash or via account.
Bank issues DD with unique number.
Beneficiary presents DD to their bank for payment.
examples: DD sent for college fee payment.
Payment order for within-city transactions.
DD purchased against cash up to ₹49,999.
facts: DD cannot be dishonoured for insufficient funds.
Payment order is like DD but for local use, valid 3 months.
Details needed: payee name, amount, place of payment.

topics.definition: Key documents used in banking for depositing, withdrawing, and tracking transactions.
key_points: Deposit slip: Used to deposit money into account.
Withdrawal slip: Used to withdraw cash from own account.
Passbook: Record of all account transactions provided by bank.
Cheque: Instrument to make payment from account to others.
processes: Fill slip with date, account details, amount in words and figures.
Submit slip at bank counter with cash/cheque.
Passbook updated periodically to show balance.
Cheque written with payee name, amount, date, signature.
examples: Pay-in slip with cash denomination details.
Passbook showing credits and debits.
Crossed cheque with “A/c Payee” marking.
facts: Overwriting on cheque not allowed.
Passbook helps track income, expenses, and savings.
Withdrawal slip can only be used by account holder for self-payment.

topics.definition: Understanding financial products, rights, duties, and ethical practices as a consumer and citizen.
key_points: Pay taxes honestly for nation’s development.
Use banking services for safety and growth of money.
Insure life and assets to manage risks.
Keep financial documents safe and confidential.
processes: Plan savings and investments.
Compare financial products before choosing.
Read terms and conditions of policies/accounts.
Safeguard passwords, PINs, cheque books.
examples: Asking for bill to ensure tax payment.
Not sharing bank details with strangers.
Nominating family members in insurance policies.
facts: Financial education helps in informed decision-making.
RBI, SEBI, IRDAI, PFRDA are financial regulators in India.
Financial inclusion aims to bring everyone into formal banking system.
